awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ontogenetic and environmental origins of pathogen disgust sensitivity
awd_abstract_narration:
It has long been proposed that the emotion of disgust helps humans avoid illness. However, levels of disgust, also called disgust sensitivity, can vary greatly among different individuals, which has implications for their behavior. In particular, research suggests that people higher in disgust sensitivity are more motivated to avoid certain objects, situations, and people. This doctoral research project investigates the broad question: why do people vary in their disgust sensitivity? One framework suggests that differences in the childhood environment may lead to differences in adult disgust sensitivity. This project is among the first to measure disgust sensitivity across a wide range of childhood ages to understand how disgust changes throughout growth and development. The researchers also examine cultural, individual, and environmental variables that may explain differences between individuals in their disgust sensitivity. These findings may be useful to health and education initiatives that focus on reducing infection risk and mitigating the progression of pandemics. Such initiatives will be aided by understanding when, why, and how children are motivated to avoid infection, and how this may vary across individuals and groups.

Infectious disease has been a longstanding feature of human societies. As a result, humans have seemingly developed cultural and biological strategies to avoid infectious exposure. Pathogen disgust sensitivity is proposed as one of the core motivational triggers to initiate avoidant behavior, yet little research has investigated how it develops during childhood or what explains variation among individuals. This project examines variables such as inflammation, energy budget, control over pathogen exposure, social learning, and gender, that may account for variation in pathogen disgust sensitivity across childhood. The researchers collect these variables using self-report and physiological measures among children 6 to 18 in two communities with distinctly different infection risk and access to resources. The empirical findings from this project will be integrated to build a biocultural understanding of individual and group variation in pathogen disgust sensitivity. Educational components of the project contribute to the goal of broadening participation in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The current project aims to fill gaps in the current pathogen disgust sensitivity (PDS) literature through two broad aims: Aim 1: to examine when and at what rate individuals acquire PDS throughout development. I expected PDS to increase with age and plateau around puberty. These results will capture the range of development across various contexts and environments, and further our understanding of the general human pattern of PDS acquirement. Aim 2: to identify variables such as inflammation, energy budget, control over pathogen exposure and gender, that may account for variation in PDS.  The overarching goal of this project is to understand how human behavioral repertoires address the enduring problem of disease risk. That is, how do individuals use behavior to mediate disease risk while having limited energy budgets?

To date, we have collected data from 175 children in Utila, Honduras, which includes responses to questionnaires, anthropometric measurements, and dried blood spot collection. Preliminary data analysis and biomarker analysis has begun, and community outreach activities have been implemented. We have analyzed dried blood spots for C-reactive protein and interleukin-6 to measure inflammation in children.

Data analysis is still preliminary; however, we have assessed patterns of PDS with age. The results suggest that, in line with our hypothesis, PDS does increase with age significantly throughout childhood. However, our results do not show a significant sex difference. Therefore, while our results illuminate the age pattern of PDS acquisition, we still do not know when the sex difference in PDS arises. Further results involving our other variables will be assessed in the future, once the dried blood spot analysis is completed. 

Our main community outreach activity to date has been returning health information back to parents, most of whom cannot afford basic healthcare. While collecting blood for dried blood spots, we also test children for anemia; parents receive this information with explanation. Additionally, we plot growth curves for parents with the anthropometric data, which is also returned with explanation.

In addition to returning results back to families, we have also trained a number of local research assistants to collect data. Once data analysis begins, we will also put together programs to be presented at schools and town hall meetings for the larger population to better understand our research project. Once data analysis is completed, results will be prepared for publication in journals such as Human Behavior and Evolution and presentation at conferences such as American Association of Biological Anthropologists. Trained local research assistants who helped collect and analyze data will be authors on such products.
